title: Wildcat Stage Productions
text:
Wildcat Stage Productions was an influential left-wing theatre and music production company based in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>. Founded in 1978 as a spin-off from the , it formed a key part of the Scottish <a href="touring%20theatre">touring theatre</a> network for the next 20 years, creating more than 80 shows and giving many thousands of performances across <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>, the <a href="UK">UK</a> and internationally. The company was named after the term for <a href="Wildcat%20strike%20action">unofficial industrial action</a>, excluding the word “<a href="theatre">theatre</a>” from its name to avoid <a href="middle-class">middle-class</a> or "<a href="bourgeois">bourgeois</a>" associations.
Wildcat launched the careers of a number of now familiar Scottish talent including <a href="Dave%20Anderson%20%28actor%29">Dave Anderson</a>, <a href="Blythe%20Duff">Blythe Duff</a>, <a href="Peter%20Mullan">Peter Mullan</a>, and <a href="Elaine%20C.%20Smith">Elaine C. Smith</a>. It also premiered "<a href="The%20Steamie">The Steamie</a>", one of the best loved pieces of popular entertainment in Scotland in the last half century. In 1997, as part of a wider review, the <a href="Scottish%20Arts%20Council">Scottish Arts Council</a>, precursor to <a href="Creative%20Scotland">Creative Scotland</a>, withdrew its funding. Despite an energetic campaign to reverse the decision, up to and including questions in Parliament, the Company was not able to continue without regular funding and eventually closed its doors a year later.
History.
The company was founded by <a href="David%20MacLennan%20%28theatre%20practitioner%29">David MacLennan</a> and <a href="Dave%20Anderson%20%28actor%29">Dave Anderson</a>. MacLennan grew up in Glasgow but was educated at <a href="Fettes%20College">Fettes College</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>, before dropping out to become a roadie for 7:84. The founder of 7:84, the writer and director <a href="John%20McGrath%20%28playwright%29">John McGrath</a>, was married to MacLennan's sister <a href="Elizabeth%20MacLennan">Elizabeth MacLennan</a> who played many of the leading roles in 7:84 productions. Brother and sister both appeared in the now legendary ceilidh play "<a href="The%20Cheviot%2C%20the%20Stag%20and%20the%20Black%20Black%20Oil">The Cheviot, the Stag and the Black Black Oil</a>" which first toured Scotland in 1973/4.
Anderson also grew up in Glasgow in a family of accomplished (but not professional) musicians (Dawson Scott, R. (August 22, 2020) personal interview). He and <a href="Alex%20Norton">Alex Norton</a>, another member of the cast of "The Cheviot", were friends from the <a href="Scottish%20folk%20music">Scottish folk music</a> circuit. At Norton’s urging, Anderson broke into his honeymoon on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Skye">Isle of Skye</a> to come and see the show and quickly became involved in the company. A shared love of <a href="rock%27n%27roll">rock'n'roll</a> and a fascination with <a href="pantomime">pantomime</a> and <a href="https%3A//www.gla.ac.uk/myglasgow/library/files/special/collections/STA/articles/music_hall/index.html">Scottish variety</a> brought the two Daves, as they became known, together. In 1977, they collaborated on a show for 7:84 about the music industry called "<a href="https%3A//www.stagesofhalfmoon.org.uk/productions/his-masters-voice/">His Master's Voice</a>", “a play in which rock music was core to the medium, rather than supporting scenes.”
Following its success, Anderson and MacLennan decided that they wanted to emphasise the musical content of their work using a more rocky and less folky sound. With McGrath’s blessing (and indeed with some left over 7:84 funding, transferred over when McGrath decided to take a sabbatical), the two of them left 7:84 to set up Wildcat along with Ferelith Lean, McLennan’s then wife, as administrator.
Operating at first out of a small office in <a href="https%3A//oldglasgow.tumblr.com/post/46281940551/whats-in-a-name-otago-street-kelvinbridge">Otago Street</a>, Glasgow, the company's first production, in September 1978, was "The Painted Bird" which addressed the then far less fashionable subject of <a href="mental%20health">mental health</a>. Co-written, as the majority of all the company’s shows were to be, by MacLennan and Anderson, it was warmly welcomed by critics and audiences alike. “Wildcat's debut on Thursday, on a ramshackle stage before a capacity house in the <a href="McLellan%20Galleries">McLellan Galleries</a>, was one of the most hopeful omens for Scotland's theatrical future” was the verdict of the <a href="Glasgow%20Herald">Glasgow Herald</a>. The company quickly won their own funding support from the Scottish Arts Council.
The company had many homes. They pioneered the use of the <a href="The%20Pleasance">Pleasance</a> Theatre in <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, now the home of a massive complex of venues during the <a href="Edinburgh%20Festival%20Fringe">Edinburgh Festival Fringe</a>. It was offered what became the Clyde Theatre in Clydebank, originally part of the <a href="Singer%20Sewing%20Machine">Singer Sewing Machine</a> site. And it also worked at the Crawfurd Theatre, part of the teacher training campus at <a href="Jordanhill%20College">Jordanhill college</a>.
All the while, the company's scale and reputation was rising steadily. Its single most successful show, "<a href="The%20Steamie">The Steamie</a>" (see below) began life as a small-scale tour in 1987. By contrast, in 1988, "<a href="http%3A//www.thecelticwiki.com/page/Celtic%2Bon%2Bstage">The Celtic Story</a>" filled the cavernous <a href="Pavilion%20Theatre%20%28Glasgow%29">Pavilion Theatre</a> in Glasgow for several weeks. Other large scale productions used the <a href="King%27s%20Theatre%2C%20Edinburgh">King's Theatre</a> in Edinburgh ("<a href="https%3A//www.faber.co.uk/9780571090419-silver-darlings.html">The Silver Darlings</a>") and the newly converted <a href="Tramway%20%28arts%20centre%29">Tramway</a> venue ("Border Warfare") in Glasgow.
These two shows represented a renewal of the connection with John McGrath who wrote and directed both. Their success led the 1996 <a href="Edinburgh%20International%20Festival">Edinburgh International Festival</a> to commission another new play from McGrath which Wildcat would produce. "A Satire of the Four Estates" was loosely based on <a href="David%20Lyndsay">Sir David Lindsay</a>'s 16th century classic <a href="Ane%20Satyre%20of%20the%20Thrie%20Estaitis">Ane Satyre of the Thrie Estaitis</a>, adding the fourth estate, <a href="Media%20%28communication%29">the media</a>, to the objects of satirical derision. With its thinly veiled and none too subtle attacks on media moguls such as <a href="Rupert%20Murdoch">Rupert Murdoch</a>, it delighted many but infuriated many more.
Whether it led directly to the Scottish Arts Council's decision to stop supporting the company financially in 1997 remains a matter of speculation. The company and its many supporters in the Labour and Trade Union movement assumed ideological reasons lay behind the move. The SAC said that the company had simply run out of creative steam.
It was a bitter blow for both MacLennan and Anderson. But their contribution to Scottish theatre did not end there. MacLennan went on to devise and then direct the hugely successful lunchtime theatre season, <a href="https%3A//playpiepint.com/">"A Play, a Pie and a Pint"</a> at Glasgow’s <a href="%C3%92ran%20M%C3%B3r">Òran Mór</a> venue until his death in 2014. Anderson continues to contribute music and lyrics across a wide range of outputs, not least the twice yearly pantomimes at Òran Mór.
Character and Style.
The company’s work was direct, boisterous, noisy and raucous. It actively engaged directly with audiences and depended heavily on the music and songs to carry both story and character. Cast members were expected to be able to sing and play at least one musical instrument as well as act. The live on-stage band and the cast were usually one and the same. It owed a lot to earlier forms of Scottish theatre, including the variety shows and seasonal pantomimes with which both Anderson and Maclennan had grown up.
Shows tended to deal with current affairs, often in an almost documentary style. Subjects ranged from the domestic, such as the 1983/4 miners strike ("Dead Liberty") to the international, such as the role of the <a href="CIA">CIA</a> in <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a> ("Business in the Back Yard") via public health ("Bedpan Alley") and education ("Jotters"). While some dismissed the company's output as "<a href="agit-prop">agit-prop</a>", others saw its political engagement and connection with popular audiences as a harbinger of greater political debates to come.
The company deliberately took its work to working class audiences across Scotland, following the model developed by 7:84, and played in modest community and village halls and working men’s clubs. But they were capable of scaling up to main stages, such as <a href="Pavilion%20Theatre%20%28Glasgow%29">The Pavilion</a> ("The Celtic Story"), the <a href="Tramway%20%28arts%20centre%29">Tramway</a> ("Border Warfare"), Edinburgh's <a href="Royal%20Lyceum%20Theatre">Royal Lyceum Theatre</a> ("Peachum's Poorhouse") and Edinburgh's <a href="Edinburgh%20International%20Conference%20Centre">International Conference Centre</a> ("A Satire of the Four Estates")
Politics.
For almost all Wildcat’s history, from 1979 to 1997, the UK was under the control of a Conservative government, lead first by Margaret Thatcher and later by John Major. The political background offered rich pickings for a group of unashamedly left-wing entertainers and the company took great delight in tweaking the noses of the landed, monied and governing classes. Their audience, often equally partisan, were quick to recognise the stereotypes with which they were presented. Thatcher was notoriously unpopular in Scotland (when she came to power in <a href="1979%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">the 1979 election</a> there were 22 Scottish Conservative MPs at Westminster; at the <a href="1992%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">1997 election</a>, when the Conservatives finally lost power overall, not a single Conservative MP survived in Scotland).
The politics of the company was largely mainstream Labour with some radical edges. Anderson recalls that he and MacLennan did not set out to be overtly political but they saw the world in a very similar ways. Anderson was never a member of any political party although MacLennan was for some years a member of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Great%20Britain">Communist Party of Great Britain</a>. The two gradually diverged over the national question, Anderson eventually becoming a supporter of <a href="Independence%20for%20Scotland">Independence for Scotland</a> while MacLennan argued against it, although he died shortly before the <a href="Independence%20referendum%2C%20Scotland">2014 Independence referendum</a>. Most Scottish MPs and local authorities at the time were controlled by Labour.
The company had close relationships with the Labour movement at all levels. <a href="Local%20government%20in%20Scotland">Local councillors</a>, such as <a href="1977%20Glasgow%20City%20District%20Council%20election">Jean Mcfadden</a>, the leader of Glasgow City Council, senior trade union officials such as <a href="Campbell%20Christie">Campbell Christie</a> and <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">members of parliament</a> such as <a href="Sam%20Galbraith">Sam Galbraith</a> and <a href="Donald%20Dewar">Donald Dewar</a> all served on the company’s board of directors at various times. The company was frequently represented at extra-parliamentary demonstrations rallies, sometimes even providing the entertainment. It was also instrumental in developing the annual <a href="International%20Workers%20Day">Mayday</a> rally organised by the Scottish TUC into <a href="List%20of%20festivals%20in%20Glasgow">Mayfest</a>, a three week long arts and politics festival in Glasgow which ran from 1983 to 1997. Ferelith Lean, the company’s administrator, was also first administrator of the festival. During its final struggle for survival, the whole company was feted at an official reception at Glasgow’s Labour controlled City Chambers in 1998.
Some notable Wildcats.
<a href="Juliet%20Cadzow">Juliet Cadzow</a>, perhaps best known as Edie Mcredie in the BBC Scotland children’s show "<a href="Balamory">Balamory</a>", first appeared for Wildcat in "Border Warfare" where she met MacLennan. They later married and he wrote a solo show for her called "An Actress Prepares", one of Wildcat's final productions.
<a href="Blythe%20Duff">Blythe Duff</a> appeared in three Wildcat productions before she was “discovered” by the producers of STV’s long running Glasgow police series"<a href="Taggart%20%28series%29">Taggart</a>" where she went onto become the series’ longest running character, Jackie Reid. She was last seen playing Professor McGonagall in "<a href="Harry%20Potter%20and%20the%20Cursed%20Child">Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</a>" before <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> closed the show.
<a href="Vivien%20Heilbron">Vivien Heilbron</a> appeared in the 1995 show "Bedfellows". She originally rose to fame as the star of BBC’s adaptation of <a href="Lewis%20Grassic%20Gibbon">Lewis Grassic Gibbon</a>'s <a href="Sunset%20Song">Sunset Song</a> in which she played Chris Guthrie.
<a href="Jimmy%20Logan">Jimmy Logan</a> appeared in "The Celtic Story". Logan was a doyen of Scottish theatre and variety. It says a lot about the status of Wildcat (and Celtic) that he agreed to appear in this show. But the fact that MacLennan had known Logan since he (MacLennan) was a child may have helped; the Logans and the MacLennans were neighbours in the <a href="Dowanhill">Dowanhill</a> area of Glasgow.
<a href="Phil%20McCall">Phil McCall</a> appeared in the 1992 show "Eight to the Bar". He was a familiar figure on stage and television, notably in series such as "<a href="Monarch%20of%20the%20Glen%20%28TV%20series%29">Monarch of the Glen</a>" and "<a href="Dr%20Finlay%E2%80%99s%20Casebook">Dr Finlay’s Casebook</a>", and was one of a number of senior actors to work for Wildcat in their later years
<a href="Peter%20Mullan%20">Peter Mullan </a> appeared with Wildcat four times in the 1980s, in "The Magic Snowball", "The Importance of Being Honest", "The Celtic Story" and "Harmony Row" (which he co-wrote). He has since become an internationally celebrated film actor and director, appearing recently in the Netflix series "<a href="Ozark%20%28TV%20series%29">Ozark</a>". He is the only person to win top prizes both for acting (<a href="Cannes%20Film%20Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> best actor award for "<a href="My%20Name%20is%20Joe">My Name is Joe</a>") and for best film (<a href="Venice%20Film%20Festival">Venice Film Festival</a> Golden lion for "<a href="The%20Magdalene%20Sisters">The Magdalene Sisters</a>") at major European film festivals.
<a href="Alex%20Norton">Alex Norton</a> directed the first production of "The Steamie". An accomplished director, actor and musician, and lifelong friend of Dave Anderson, he was best known as DCI Matt Burke in "<a href="Taggart%20%28series%29">Taggart</a>", STV’s long running Glasgow police drama, but has enjoyed recent acclaim success in the comedy series "Two Doors Down," in which he has bene reunited with Elaine C.Smith. Norton first introduced Anderson to MacLennan after a performance of "The Cheviot, the Stag and the Black Black Oil" on the Isle of Skye.
<a href="Elaine%20C.%20Smith">Elaine C. Smith</a> was a regular with the company in its, and her, early days. After appearing with Dave Anderson in the TV sitcom "City Lights" she has gone on become one of Scotland’s best loved stage and screen personalities, notably as Mary Doll, the wife of <a href="Rab%20C.%20Nesbitt">Rab C. Nesbitt</a>, portraying X-Factor sensation <a href="Susan%20Boyle">Susan Boyle</a>, and more recently for her role in the sitcom <a href="Two%20Doors%20Down">Two Doors Down</a> which also features Alex Norton.
<a href="Tony%20Roper%20%28actor%29">Tony Roper</a> wrote Wildcat’s biggest popular success, "The Steamie", a piece of New Year's Eve nostalgia set in one of Glasgow’s <a href="Laundry%23Washhouses">communal washhouses</a>. Roper had been a regular foil to <a href="Rikki%20Fulton">Rikki Fulton</a> in the long running comedy series <a href="Scotch%20and%20Wry">Scotch and Wry</a> and also appeared as Jamesie Cotter, best pal of <a href="Rab%20C.%20Nesbitt">Rab C. Nesbitt</a>.
<a href="Liz%20Lochhead">Liz Lochhead</a>, the poet and playwright, co-wrote "Bunch of Fives" for Wildcat in 1983. She went on to become Scotland’s <a href="Makar">Makar</a> (roughly equivalent to England’s <a href="Poet%20Laureate">Poet Laureate</a>) and was appointed life president of the <a href="Scottish%20Society%20of%20Playwrights">Scottish Society of Playwrights</a> in 2019
<a href="John%20Sampson%20%28musician%29">John Sampson (musician)</a>, multi-instrumental musician, actor and entertainer. Sampson is notable for his collaboration with Britain's poet laureate <a href="Carol%20Ann%20Duffy">Carol Ann Duffy</a> in live performances since 2003. He was short listed for the Critic's Award for Theatre in Scotland in the Best Music and Sound category for his work on "<a href="A%20Taste%20of%20Honey">A Taste of Honey</a>", <a href="Royal%20Lyceum%20Theatre%20Company">Royal Lyceum Theatre Company</a>, Edinburgh. He has appeared in eight Wildcat productions.
